questions.question: A patient is brought to the casualty following a head injury. He is unconscious and is not ableto open his eyes. He also has no verbal or motor responses. What will be his GCS score?
A patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli,and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is
questions.explanation: The GCS in this patient is 11.•The score for verbal response: 4, because he is confused.• The score for eye-opening: 2, because his eyes are opening to only painful stimuli.• The score for best motor response: 5, because he can localize pain.Therefore, the GCS score is (4+2+5) = 11.1011

questions.question: After assessing a patient with a traumatic head injury, a score of 3 was given for motorresponse. According to the Glasgow Coma Scale, what does the score indicate?1003
questions.explanation: Motor response of 3 indicates decorticate posture or abnormal flexion to pain stimulus.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the casualty ward with a history of road traffic accidentand head trauma. She opens her eyes to pain, moans, can localize her limb towards the painstimulus on the left hand and away from the pain stimulus on the right hand and both thelegs are in extended posture. Calculate her GCS.
questions.explanation: The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of this patient is E2V2M5, which comes to a total score of 9.•-E2 Eye opens to pain• V2 Moans•⚫ M5 - Localizes to pain on the left hand (the score represents the best performance elicited, whichwould be localized towards the pain stimulus)

questions.question: Which of the following head injury patients need not undergo head CT at this point in time?

options.A: An RTA victim with GCS score of 12
options.B: A patient with an episode of vomiting
options.C: A child with an episode of seizure post-trauma
options.D: A biker with suspected skull fracture

questions.explanation: A single episode of vomiting after a head injury is not an indication for immediate CT brain.However, more than one episode mandates a scan.

questions.question: A 26-year-old batsman was rushed to the ER when he fell unconscious after a cricket ball hithis head. He regained consciousness later but started to deteriorate rapidly. A plain CT of thepatient is shown below. What is the diagnosis?1004
questions.explanation: The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image are suggestive of extraduralhematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdensebiconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect.Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. Itusually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. It lies behindthe pterion, which is the thinnest part of the skull.In EDH, the patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. Thepatient then awakens and has a “lucid interval," while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. Asthe volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidlybecomes lethargic and herniates.Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateralhemiparesis.

questions.question: An alcoholic patient was brought to the casualty after he was found lying near a ditch. He hada laceration over his scalp. His GCS on arrival was 13 and after a few minutes, it dropped to10. A plain CT scan was done and given below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan showing a concavo-convex shaped hematoma onthe left side with a midline shift to the right is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).1013An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane andthe dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to thedural sinuses.The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as thehematoma expands.Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma dueto brain atrophy.Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:•• Thickness >1 cm•Midline shift >5 mm•Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) drops by two or more points from the time of injury tohospitalization.

questions.question: A 70-year-old man presents with headache, vomiting, and altered sensorium for the past 6hours. His wife reports him having a fall in the bathroom 4 weeks ago. On evaluation, thefollowing funduscopic findings are noted. What will be your provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and fundus examination are most probably suggestive of chronicsubdural hematoma. The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin whichis suggestive of papilledema.Chronic SDH is a collection of blood breakdown products that are at least 2 to 3 weeks old. Itoccurs in patients without a clear history of head trauma, as they may arise from a minor headinjury. Alcoholics, the elderly, and patients on anticoagulation are at higher risk for developingchronic SDH than others.Patients may present with headaches, seizures, confusion, contralateral hemiparesis, or coma.A chronic SDH >1 cm or any symptomatic SDH should be surgically drained.Nomencla TimetureAcute SD<3 dayHSSubacuteSDHChronic SDH4-21 days> 21 days

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presented with a sudden onset severe headache and vomiting. His medicalrecord revealed he has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. On examination, pulse- 100 bpm, BP - 190/110 mm Hg, marked neck rigidity was present and no neurologicaldeficits were noted. What could be the most likely cause of the symptoms?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) due to the rupture ofa berry aneurysm. It is an extrarenal manifestation of autosomal dominant polycystic kidneydisease.1014Clinical features of SAH:• Sudden-onset severe headache (thunderclap headache)• Rapid onset vomiting• Confusion or a lowered level of consciousness•Seizures• Meningitic features of neck stiffness and photophobia often develop over hours.The most common cause is trauma and is managed conservatively. The second most commoncause is a rupture of a berry aneurysm.CT scan is the investigation of choice. A hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoidspace. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority ofberry aneurysms occurring in this region.A lumbar puncture should be performed if the CT scan fails to establish the diagnosis of SAH. Itwill show xanthochromic CSF.Delayed ischemic neurological deficit (DIND) is attributed to vasospasm of the cerebralvasculature typically developing 3-10 days following ictus. It is the main cause of a poor outcome.Management:.• Endovascular treatment ("coiling") is generally preferred over craniotomy and clipping foraneurysms amenable to this approach.• The combination of induced hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution (Triple-H therapy) isoften utilized to prevent and treat cerebral vasospasm after aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage(SAH).Note: The combination of subarachnoid hemorrhage and vitreous hemorrhage (subhyaloid) isknown as Terson syndrome.1015

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding delayed ischemic neurological deficit?

options.A: It is seen in subarachnoid haemorrhage
options.C: It is attributed to cerebral vasospasm

questions.explanation: Delayed ischemic neurological deficit (DIND) usually occurs between 3 and 10 days after the SAH.It is a delayed complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage characterized by the fluctuating declinein consciousness and appearance of neurological deficits. It is attributed to ischemia resultingfrom reactive cerebral vasospasm. Patients with a larger blood load (in the subarachnoid space)are at higher risk of vasospasm.Medical management strategies aim to minimize secondary brain injury, through avoidance ofhypoxia and hypotension and control of ICP.The incidence of DIND can be lowered by prophylaxis with nimodipine (60 mg, 4 hourly) andhypervolemia (8 hourly normal saline).

questions.question: A 26-year-old formula one driver was rushed to the casualty, unconscious, following a heavycrash from a side-impact collision during a racing event. The CT scan was normal. However,MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages, especially in the corpus callosum and thedorsolateral midbrain, with no midline shift. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a normal CT and MRI showing evidence of hemorrhages in thecorpus callosum and midbrain is probably due to a diffuse axonal injury.A diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is causedby damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration.Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice).Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. Theprognosis is very poor.MRI showing multiple hypointense punctate foci within the subcortical and deep white matterwithin the corpus callosum is characteristic of diffuse axonal injury.

questions.question: According to the Glasgow Outcome Score, what score will you give to a patient who is in apersistent vegetative state following a head injury?
questions.explanation: 1016A persistent vegetative state is given a score of 2, according to the Glasgow Outcome Score.The Glasgow Outcome Scale (GOS) is different from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), and it is usedto quantify the degree of recovery achieved after a head injury, especially for research purposes.The scoring system is as follows:Patient conditionGood recoveryModerate disabilitySevere disabilityPersistent vegetative stateDeadScorD5LO43211

questions.question: A patient is recovering from a spinal shock after a fall from height. Which of the following isthe first reflex that you will expect to reappear in him?1007
questions.explanation: Bulbocavernosus reflex is the first reflex to return after the spinal shock has resolved.It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis in males and applying pressure to the clitoris or pullingthe Foleys catheter in females. Any of these will lead to anal sphincter contraction.Spinal shock is a condition of transient physiologic reflex depression of spinal cord function.(motor, sensory, tone, reflexes) below the level of injury. It usually results from a high-impact,direct trauma to the spinal cord. When the level of injury is above T6, it can result inhemodynamic changes such as hypotension and bradycardia (due to loss of sympathetic tone andunopposed parasympathetic function).The resolution of spinal shock occurs over a period of days to months, when the areflexia slowlytransitions to hyperreflexia and spasticity. Reflexes return sequentially rather thansimultaneously. The resolution of the somatic component of spinal shock is classically signaled bythe return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, a polysynaptic cutaneous spinal reflex (mediated by theconus medullaris) which is then followed by monosynaptic deep tendon reflexes (e.g. ankle jerk).1017SqueezingclitorisBulbocavernosus reflexSqueezingglansAfferentpudendalS2-S4sacral centerRROOMARROWEfferentpudendalAnal sphinctercontraction

questions.question: Which of the following is not used for managing a patient with raised intracranial pressurefollowing a head injury?
questions.explanation: Steroids are not used in severe head injury, since they are associated with increased mortality.Initial management of raised intracranial pressure (ICP):•• Airway protection• Positioning the head up 20-30° (reverse Trendelenburg positioning)• A bolus of mannitol up to 1 g/kg for free water diuresis (the effect is delayed by 20 min).Hypertonic saline (3% or 5%)•• Maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance•Seizure control•Sedation using a combination of opiates and barbiturates• Ventriculostomy and/or craniectomy may be needed for definitive decompression.ICP normally varies between 4 and 14 mmHg. Sustained ICP levels above 25 mmHg can injure thebrain. The goal of therapy in raised ICP is to maintain the ICP 20 - 25 mmHg.Note: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation through the foramen magnum compresses medullaryvasomotor and respiratory centers, classically producing Cushing's triad. It is comprised of:• Bradycardia• Raised blood pressure.• Irregular respirations.

questions.question: In patients with head trauma, which of the following is least likely to cause secondary braininjuries?
questions.explanation: 1018Hypercapnea (and not hypocapnea) is a cause of secondary brain injury.It is essential to avoid hypercapnia in patients with head injury since it will raise intracranialpressure (ICP). While hyperventilation is an effective way of managing acute intracranialhypertension, it should be remembered that it can produce a dangerous decrease in cerebral bloodflow, especially if cerebral perfusion pressure is low.Primary brain injury (focal and diffuse) results from mechanical injury at the time of the trauma.Secondary brain injury is caused by the physiologic responses to the initial injury. This is thoughtto involve a cascade of events, with edema and hematomas leading to increased intracranialpressure, which leads to compression and deformation of surrounding brain tissue and furtherdamage.Causes of secondary brain injury:•⚫ Hypoxia• Hypotension• Raised ICP >20 mmHg• Low cerebral perfusion pressure•Hypercapnea•• Hyperthermia• Seizures• Metabolic disturbance (hyperglycemia)

questions.question: A patient with a head injury presents to the casualty with rapidly deteriorating sensorium andprogressive dilatation and fixation of the pupil. Neurosurgeon and CT scan are not available.The duty surgeon decides to make a burr hole. What will be the management plan?

options.A: Make a hole in the temporal region, contralateral to the side of pupillary dilatation.
options.B: Make a hole in the midline, if both pupils are equal or it is not known which side dilated first.
options.C: If no localizing sign is found, make a hole in the left temporal region.
options.D: Refer to higher center if both pupils are equal or it is not known which side dilated first

questions.explanation: In the given situation, no localizing sign is found and it is not known which side dilated first. So,the best choice would be to do a burr hole in the dominant hemisphere (most commonly, the lefttemporal region).Determination of burr hole sitePatient with a head injuryPupil dilatedon one sideBoth thepupils dilatedNo localizationcluesBurr hole onthat sideRRBurr hole onthe left sideOne side dilatedfirst and knownBurr hole onthat sideOMARROW1019First dilated sideis not knownBurr hole on theside of obviousexternal trauma

questions.question: 1008Which of the following is true regarding post-traumatic seizures in patients with head injury?

options.A: Use of antiepileptics in late post-traumatic seizure patients is recommended
options.B: Prolonged seizures cause primary brain injury post head trauma
options.C: Occurrence of seizures after 2 weeks of head injury is called late post-traumatic seizures
options.D: Initiation of antiepileptics in early post traumatic seizure patients reduces the likelihood ofdeveloping post-traumatic epilepsy

questions.explanation: The use of antiepileptics in late post-traumatic seizure (PTS) patients is recommended.Post-traumatic seizures (PTS) are seizures that result from traumatic brain injury (TBI). They areclassified into early and late. Early PTS occurs within 1 week and late PTS occurs after 1 week oftrauma (Option C).Early PTS are acute symptomatic events, attributed to a direct reaction to injury and hemorrhage.Risk factors for early PTS are:•• Younger age (especially <5 years)• Moderate to severe head injury (measured by GCS)•• Acute intracerebral hematoma• Subdural/Subarachnoid hemorrhage•Depressed skull fractures• Diffuse cerebral edema.•History of alcohol abuse•• Penetrating head injuryLate PTS usually occurs due to underlying permanent structural and physiologic changes withinthe brain. Patients with late PTS may develop post-traumatic epilepsy (PTE). It refers to recurrentand unprovoked PTS that occur at least 1 week after TBI. Risk factors for PTE are:• Early PTS• Severe head injury• Older age (especially >65 years)• Focal neurological deficit• Intracranial hemorrhage.• Intracranial infection• Abnormalities on EEG• Alcohol-related head injuryProlonged seizures (30 to 60 minutes) can cause secondary brain injury, not primary (Option B).Hence, it is imperative to control acute seizures as soon as possible.The initiation of antiepileptics in early PTS patients is to prevent damage due to seizuresthemselves. It does not reduce the likelihood of developing PTE (Option D). For patients whodevelop late PTS, because of the high risk of seizure recurrence after the first episode of late PTS,the use of antiepileptic medication is recommended even after a single late seizure episode. Thelong-term sequelae of head injury are headache, raised ICP, impaired short-term memory, lack ofconcentration, emotional disinhibition, and depression.1020Prophylaxis for PTS is indicated in patients at risk of early PTS, for 7 days and is stopped withouttapering the dose if no seizures have occurred during this duration. Prophylaxis is notrecommended for late PTS.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding basilar skull fractures?

options.A: Racoon eyes is one of the earliest signs to develop
options.B: Battle sign is associated with posterior cranial fossa fractures
options.C: CSF leaks should be promptly managed by surgical intervention
options.D: Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided

questions.explanation: Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation should be avoided in patients with basilar skull fracturesdue to the risk of pneumocephalus.Signs in basilar skull fractures:•Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture ofthe temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.• Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated withfractures of the anterior cranial fossa.•⚫ Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoidregion is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa.•⚫ CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: "Halo" sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containingbloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and aredelayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF isconfirmed by testing for ẞ2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistentleaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilarskull fractures due to the risk for intracranial placement. NIPPV is avoided due to the risk forpneumocephalus.The image below shows the 'battle' sign.1021The image below shows 'racoon' eyes.The image below shows pneumocephalus.

questions.question: A man is brought to the ER with a depressed skull fracture and a clean overlying scalplaceration. There are no focal neurological deficits. CT scan revealed that the degree ofdepression was less than the thickness of the adjacent skull bone. What is the next step in themanagement of the patient?

options.A: Surgically elevate the depressed segment and close the laceration with sutures
options.B: Provide prophylactic antibiotics and discharge the patient
options.D: Apply dressing and discharge the patient

questions.explanation: In the given scenario, the next step is to close the laceration with suture.The management of the depressed skull fractures:• The first step is to order a CT scan to know the degree of depression and to exclude the presenceof an intracranial hematoma or contusion.• The depressed fracture is elevated and managed as an open fracture (surgery) if:• The degree of depression is greater than the thickness of the adjacent skull1022• The wound is are open and grossly contaminated• There are focal neurological deficits•Less severe depressed fractures are managed by the closure of the overlying scalp laceration, ifpresent.
